Statistics done ALMOST right - an SPSS syntax recipe book Bernard Liew 2022-04-14 Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Where did this book come from? No I do not want people to fail in statistics if that is what you are thinking. On the contrary, I want to help people who hate statistics pass it and use it well. Statistics involve multiple back and forth stages including getting data ready for performing the statistics, understanding various statistical tests, knowing what statistical test to choose, executing the test, reporting the results, and plotting I may have probably forgotten a few steps. You get the point - it is convoluted. What most statistical classes do not teach too well, if at all, is learning how to get data ready for any statistics. Cleaning data and getting it ready will likely eat up >70% of your time. Statistics per se is quick!!! Most people interact with SPSS using what I call the point and click interface. A point-click method is not wrong per se, I use it. The bad thing about the point-click method is that: You cannot easily remember what you did. Try recalling the exact order of actions you undertook the last time you analyzed your data in SPSS. It is for this reason that one gets nervous reproducing the results. It gets tedious quickly, especially if you want to do the same thing repeatedly. The alternative to the point and click interface, is using the SPSS syntax. The syntax is all about typing. You can open a fresh syntax like in Figure 1.1, populate it with commands to run, and save it. My rule of thumb is when you spend so long getting something running, save your effort, not your the consequence of that effort. Figure 1.1: Open your first syntax Figure 1.2 shows what a full syntax looks like when you string together a bunch of commands. Figure 1.2: What a full syntax looks like 1.2 What this book offers? This book offers you very common cut-and-paste style recipes to tidy your dirty data to get it ready for statistics, and recipes for common statistical methods. I have taken the liberty to select some default settings on all the statistical tests. These default settings I believe, even though not necessarily 100% right, very closely approximate the right answers. For novices, this book will be all you need to execute basic statistical tests in SPSS. 1.3 Who this book isnt for? This book is not for connoisseurs of statistics. If you find yourself disagreeing a lot with the default parameters I use for the syntax, you likely need resources beyond this book. However, if you do find errors, strongly feel that a better default should be used, or want more recipes added, do contact me.

63 sjbw 1 2 G 34 42.30 161 POST L 2 4 64 32 63 sjbw 2 2 G 34 42.30 161 POST L 2 4 64 32 63 sjbw 0 Download data 2.1 Recipe 1 - Paste to syntax If you can develop one habit, it is this!!! The good thing about interacting with SPSS using syntax, is that you do not have to be a total syntax convert. You can continue using the point and click interface, but instead of executing the command, press paste as you see in Figure 2.1. Pasting automatically copies the word version of what you clicked into your opened syntax. Figure 2.1: Paste the syntax you generated implicitly by clicking I have not ever encountered an SPSS function that does not eventually have a paste function. Try finding it and saving what you intend to do like in Figure 2.2. Figure 2.2: Always try to paste your syntax rather than executing To run each command, highlight and press the play button like in Figure 2.3. Figure 2.3: Executing a command 2.2 Recipe 2 - Setting your work directory When importing data from deeply nested folders, can be a pain to do so. In addition, when exporting files or figures, many often scratch their head as to where the files went to. The solution to this is to explicitly define the folder on your computer where everything starts and ends. All the files will be exported to that folder. And importing becomes a breeze. You can set the working directory by pasting the command below into your SPSS syntax, and changing the folder path to your path. Just make sure to enclose it in " ". cd 'C:\Box\myBox\Documents\teaching\Statistics\SPSS\wrangling\Essex_SPSS_summer\data'. 2.3 Recipe 3 - Importing data The most common starting point for data analysis is Excel, so I will demonstrate how to easily import an Excel file. Paste the command below into your syntax, and simply change the file name df.xlsx to whatever your file is named. Remember not to change the file extension .xlsx. Notice I did not do this "'C:\Box\myBox\Documents\teaching\Statistics\SPSS\wrangling\Essex_SPSS_summer\data\df.xlsx'". It was because I already defined the path the file was in Recipe 2.2. If your Excel file has multiple sheets, change the sheet name jump to whatever it is named. If you only have one sheet, you can leave it blank. GET DATA /TYPE=XLSX /FILE= 'df.xlsx' /SHEET=name 'jump' /CELLRANGE=FULL /READNAMES=ON /DATATYPEMIN PERCENTAGE=95.0 /HIDDEN IGNORE=YES. Using the sample data I provide, this is what the data looks like in Figure 2.4. Figure 2.4: Original data 2.4 Recipe 4 - Rename columns Renaming columns is a common task. Paste the command below into your syntax and run it. Put all the original column names before the = and all the new names after. There must be spacing between each name, and the order preceding and proceeding with the = must be identical. RENAME VARIABLES (subj group wt = id grp weight). After renaming, this is what the data looks like in Figure 2.5. Figure 2.5: New column names 2.5 Recipe 5 - Filter rows You might want to keep rows in your data based on some conditions. I tend to prefer to keep whatever rows I want and discard the remaining. Discarding your data does not harm your original data in Excel. If you change your mind, just highlight all the commands from the start and press the play button. In the example below, I want to keep rows where the variable task is equal to"cmjbw" AND side is equal to R. Below are some of the operators you can mix and match to powerfully filter your data. Symbols Meaning = Equal ~= Not equal < Less than <= Less than or equal > More than >= More than or equal & AND | OR FILTER OFF. USE ALL. SELECT IF (task = "cmjbw" & side = "R"). EXECUTE. After filtering, this is what the data looks like in Figure 2.6. Figure 2.6: Keeping rows based on some conditions 2.6 Recipe 6 - Create new variables You might want to create new variables, such as calculating BMI from height and mass. Add as many COMPUTE functions below as needed. The command reads as COMPUTE height = ht/100., make a new variable called height by dividing the original variableht by 100. You can either create a new variable or replace the existing variable by using a new name or the original name, respectively. Math functions + Add - Subtract / Divide * Multiply ** Power COMPUTE height = ht/100. COMPUTE weight = weight/100. COMPUTE BMI = weight/(height**2). EXECUTE. After computing new variables, this is what the data looks like in Figure 2.7. Figure 2.7: New variables created 2.7 Recipe 7 - Group by function Many times you want to do the same thing repeatedly on certain chunks of data. For example, you want to find the mean strength on each level of sex (male, female), or even each level of the combination of sex-side (male-right, male-left, female-right, female-left). Precede whatever function you want to execute, with the command below. In the command below, I want to do the same analysis for each level of the combination of grp and time. This works for categorical variables. Replace grp and time with however many variables you want to split the data by. PS This means you can run the same stats on each split of the data by running the stats only once if you use this command. SORT CASES BY grp time. SPLIT FILE SEPARATE BY grp time. After grouping the data, when I ran a descriptive analysis, this is what the results looks like in Figure 2.8. Figure 2.8: Group-by descriptives 2.8 Recipe 8 - Aggregate data You may want to find some summary statistics for each level of a grouping variable. In the example below, I want to calculate for each id, in each group, at each time, find the mean (MEAN), minimum (MIN), maximum (MAX), standard deviation (SD), and median (MEDIAN) of the following variables (aexttorq, aextwork, aextpow). When you see this argument, /aexttorq_mean=MEAN(aexttorq), the value before = represents the new variable name. However many aggregate values you desire, add as many arguments on a separate line. In this command, the aggregate data is pasted onto a separate data window called aggregate_data - you can give the new data window any name. DATASET DECLARE aggregate_data. AGGREGATE /OUTFILE='aggregate_data' /BREAK=id grp time /aexttorq_mean=MEAN(aexttorq) /aextwork_min=MIN(aextwork) /aextpow_max=MAX(aextpow) /aexttorq_sd=SD(aexttorq) /aextwork_median=MEDIAN(aextwork). After aggregating, this is what the data looks like in Figure 2.9. Figure 2.9: Aggregated summary 2.9 Recipe 9 - Long to wide The two key commands are /ID=id grp and /INDEX=time. /ID represents how each data point will be uniquely identified. /INDEX represents the variable you want to spread by. Notice that Recipe 2.9 and 2.10 are mirror images. the /ID command in Recipe 10 should be identical to the /KEEP in Recipe 2.9. The /INDEX in both Recipes 2.9 and 2.10 should contain the variable name you want to spread by. CASESTOVARS /ID=id grp /INDEX=time /GROUPBY=VARIABLE. Figure 2.10: Wide data 2.10 Recipe 10 - Wide to long Typically data is keyed into Excel in the wide-format like in Figure 2.10. In > 90% of any data analysis, data should NOT be in this format. The only thing I know in SPSS that requires data to be in the wide-format is when you want to use Repeated Measures Anova or a Paired t-test. So it is useful to know how to convert data to a long format since > 90% of SPSS function requires data to be in a long format. /MAKE aexttorq_mean FROM aexttorq_mean.POST aexttorq_mean.PRE says to collect all the variables aexttorq_mean.POST, aexttorq_mean.PRE and stack their values on top of each other. The column containing the values is called aexttorq_mean. The column where the names of the values are stored is called time. Remember, you can call the new columns anything you want. /KEEP=id grp simply says keep the following columns in the new data. VARSTOCASES /MAKE aexttorq_mean FROM aexttorq_mean.POST aexttorq_mean.PRE /INDEX=time"POST, PRE" /KEEP=id grp /NULL=KEEP. After running the command, this is what the results looks like in Figure 2.11. Figure 2.11: Long data 2.11 Conclusion Notice how I did not even touch on saving any outputs. The reason for that is that one should first save all the commands ran rather than the results. Saving the process allows you to replicate your actions, saving your results will not.

Chapter 3 Exploration 3.1 Descriptive statistics You want to find some summary statistics like averages, standard deviation of some variables. 3.1.1 What your data needs to look like? 3.1.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: VARIABLES: Change the value atorq to the name of your dependent variable. You can even add many variables, with a space between them. As the name suggests, I am asking SPSS to spit out the average, standard deviation, variance, range, minimum, and maximum values. DESCRIPTIVES VARIABLES=atorq /STATISTICS=MEAN STDDEV VARIANCE RANGE MIN MAX. 3.2 QQ plot You want to check for normality of distribution of a variable. 3.2.1 Syntax Arguments to care about: /VARIABLES: Change the value atorq to the name of your dependent variable. You can add as many variables one after the other, each with a spacing. PPLOT /VARIABLES=atorq /NOLOG /NOSTANDARDIZE /TYPE=Q-Q /FRACTION=BLOM /TIES=MEAN /DIST=NORMAL.

Chapter 4 Simpler statistics 4.1 One-sample t test Hypothesis Is the ankle torque of my sample really different from 60 Nm/kg? 4.1.1 What your data needs to look like? subj atorq 1 74.12500 2 53.93750 3 71.96875 4 80.87500 5 79.50916 6 99.75000 7 84.40625 8 115.90625 9 89.68750 10 67.21875 11 79.31250 12 75.21875 14 88.40625 15 86.00000 16 111.46875 17 76.21875 18 73.40625 19 98.71875 20 92.03125 21 94.34375 22 101.71875 23 56.34375 Download data 4.1.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: /VARIABLES: Change the value atorq to the name of your dependent variable /TESTVAL: Change the value to the mean you want to compare it against. In this example, I am asking is my ankle torque of my sample really different from 0? T-TEST /TESTVAL=60 /MISSING=ANALYSIS /VARIABLES=atorq /ES DISPLAY(TRUE) /CRITERIA=CI(.95). For reporting, please see Chapter 6.1. 4.1.3 Non parametric equivalent Arguments to care about: Change the value atorq to the name of your dependent variable NPTESTS /ONESAMPLE TEST (atorq) /MISSING SCOPE=ANALYSIS USERMISSING=EXCLUDE /CRITERIA ALPHA=0.05 CILEVEL=95 SEED=RANDOM. 4.2 Independent t-test Hypothesis Is the ankle torque from one group different from a separate group? 4.2.1 What your data needs to look like? subj group atorq 1 G 74.12500 2 G 53.93750 3 T 71.96875 4 G 80.87500 5 T 79.50916 6 T 99.75000 7 G 84.40625 8 G 115.90625 9 T 89.68750 10 T 67.21875 11 T 79.31250 12 G 75.21875 14 T 88.40625 15 G 86.00000 16 T 111.46875 17 G 76.21875 18 T 73.40625 19 T 98.71875 20 G 92.03125 21 G 94.34375 22 T 101.71875 23 T 56.34375 Download data 4.2.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: GROUPS: Change the variable group to the name of your independent grouping variable. Also change G and T to the names of the levels within the grouping variable /VARIABLES: Change atorq to the name of your dependent variable. T-TEST GROUPS=group('G' 'T') /MISSING=ANALYSIS /VARIABLES=atorq /ES DISPLAY(TRUE) /CRITERIA=CI(.95). For reporting, please see Chapter 6.2. 4.2.3 Non parametric equivalent Arguments to care about: Change the value atorq to the name of your dependent variable, and group to the name of your independent variable. NPTESTS /INDEPENDENT TEST (atorq) GROUP (group) /MISSING SCOPE=ANALYSIS USERMISSING=EXCLUDE /CRITERIA ALPHA=0.05 CILEVEL=95. 4.3 Paired t-test Hypothesis Is the ankle torque in the same group of subjects different after compared to before a training program? 4.3.1 What your data needs to look like? subj POST PRE 1 79.8750 68.3750 2 61.3750 46.5000 4 98.8750 62.8750 7 98.5625 70.2500 8 131.3750 100.4375 12 74.8750 75.5625 15 98.4375 73.5625 17 86.2500 66.1875 20 103.0625 81.0000 21 123.2500 65.4375 Download data 4.3.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: PAIRS: Change the variables POST and PRE to the name of the paired variables you are testing. T-TEST PAIRS=POST WITH PRE (PAIRED) /ES DISPLAY(TRUE) STANDARDIZER(CORRECTED_SD) /CRITERIA=CI(.9500) /MISSING=ANALYSIS. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.3. 4.3.3 Non parametric equivalent Arguments to care about: Change the variables POST and PRE to the name of the paired variables you are testing. NPTESTS /RELATED TEST(POST PRE) /MISSING SCOPE=ANALYSIS USERMISSING=EXCLUDE /CRITERIA ALPHA=0.05 CILEVEL=95. 4.4 One-way between ANOVA Hypothesis Is the ankle torque different across the three independent groups? If yes, where do the differences lie? 4.4.1 What your data needs to look like? subj group atorq 1 1 68.37500 1 2 79.87500 2 1 46.50000 2 2 61.37500 3 3 71.96875 4 1 62.87500 4 2 98.87500 5 3 79.50916 6 3 99.75000 7 1 70.25000 7 2 98.56250 8 1 100.43750 8 2 131.37500 9 3 89.68750 10 3 67.21875 11 3 79.31250 12 1 75.56250 12 2 74.87500 14 3 88.40625 15 1 73.56250 15 2 98.43750 16 3 111.46875 17 1 66.18750 17 2 86.25000 18 3 73.40625 19 3 98.71875 20 1 81.00000 20 2 103.06250 21 1 65.43750 21 2 123.25000 22 3 101.71875 23 3 56.34375 Download data 4.4.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: Change the variables atorq and group to the names of your dependent and independent variables, respectively ONEWAY atorq BY group /ES=OVERALL /STATISTICS DESCRIPTIVES /MISSING ANALYSIS /CRITERIA=CILEVEL(0.95) /POSTHOC=LSD T3 ALPHA(0.05). For reporting, please see Chapter 6.4. 4.5 One-way within ANOVA Hypothesis Is the ankle torque of the same group different across multiple sessions? If yes, where do the differences lie? 4.5.1 What your data needs to look like? subj after post pre 1 79.8750 65.375 71.37500 2 61.3750 40.500 52.50000 3 81.8125 53.375 70.87500 4 98.8750 59.500 66.25000 5 95.0625 64.750 63.16164 6 114.5625 82.750 87.12500 7 98.5625 68.375 72.12500 8 131.3750 104.125 96.75000 9 98.6250 91.375 70.12500 10 71.8125 60.000 65.25000 11 78.8750 78.625 80.87500 12 74.8750 82.375 68.75000 14 95.9375 81.750 80.00000 15 98.4375 60.500 86.62500 16 130.4375 94.375 90.62500 17 86.2500 58.250 74.12500 18 82.6250 60.375 68.00000 19 110.5000 86.125 87.75000 20 103.0625 89.500 72.50000 21 123.2500 61.750 69.12500 22 110.3750 80.000 106.12500 23 62.1250 45.250 55.87500 Download data 4.5.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: GLM. Add the names of all the variables (i.e. pre, post, after). These three variables actually represent the three categories of a common variable, which in this context we call session. You can given any name to this common variable. /WSFACTOR. Change session to any name you want to denote the categories within your repeated measures. /MEASURE. Change atorq to the name of your dependent variable. /EMMEANS. Change session to any name you want to denote the categories within your repeated measures. /WSDESIGN. Change session to any name you want to denote the categories within your repeated measures. GLM pre post after /WSFACTOR=session 3 Polynomial /MEASURE=atorq /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /PRINT=ETASQ PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /WSDESIGN=session. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.5. 4.6 Correlation Hypothesis Are the variables of ankle torque, ankle work, knee torque, and knee work correlated with each other? 4.6.1 What your data needs to look like? subj atorq awork apow ktorq kwork kpow 1 70 34 58 111 107 92 2 72 36 70 137 113 139 3 73 37 67 160 130 136 4 73 35 69 137 115 121 5 72 36 65 160 140 164 6 72 32 51 163 139 165 7 67 34 63 157 133 155 8 72 36 66 165 145 158 9 66 33 62 145 117 128 10 59 31 57 147 160 153 11 66 33 66 149 168 138 12 63 32 65 146 165 150 13 64 33 63 170 168 165 14 72 37 60 151 173 158 15 66 33 67 171 187 178 16 67 34 49 162 180 156 17 74 38 70 125 129 128 18 76 40 69 139 144 146 19 77 39 64 130 130 134 20 80 40 68 129 137 132 21 86 45 77 166 167 171 22 88 45 77 168 168 159 23 89 46 77 168 166 154 24 85 43 61 169 168 173 25 73 38 75 140 149 131 26 79 42 76 135 153 118 27 78 41 59 157 168 156 28 76 38 51 144 157 144 29 79 40 59 158 168 119 30 81 42 82 169 184 173 31 78 41 72 146 164 150 32 79 42 82 165 177 165 33 52 25 52 94 96 97 34 54 27 56 91 96 93 35 60 28 52 92 98 94 36 56 27 56 90 93 92 37 47 23 48 100 87 92 38 47 24 49 96 98 100 39 50 26 52 95 102 99 40 54 26 56 96 104 100 41 41 20 18 107 112 108 42 44 22 42 105 106 106 43 42 20 37 109 116 105 44 41 20 38 101 106 100 45 42 20 23 108 109 110 46 41 20 41 106 113 105 47 40 19 37 104 105 106 48 33 17 25 104 109 105 49 60 31 53 96 93 32 50 66 34 56 97 94 99 Download data 4.6.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: /VARIABLE. Add the names of all the variables (i.e. atorq, awork, apow, ktorq) you want to find a correlation. CORRELATIONS /VARIABLES=atorq awork apow ktorq /PRINT=TWOTAIL NOSIG FULL /CI CILEVEL(95) BIAS(TRUE) /MISSING=PAIRWISE. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.6.

Chapter 5 Tougher statistics 5.1 Two (or more) way between ANOVA Hypothesis Do different strength training methods (G and T) result in different ankle torque, and is the difference dependent on supplement intake (NO and YES)? 5.1.1 What your data needs to look like? subj group supplement atorq 1 G NO 68.37500 1 G YES 79.87500 2 G NO 46.50000 2 G YES 61.37500 3 T NO 62.12500 3 T YES 81.81250 4 G NO 62.87500 4 G YES 98.87500 5 T NO 63.95582 5 T YES 95.06250 6 T NO 84.93750 6 T YES 114.56250 7 G NO 70.25000 7 G YES 98.56250 8 G NO 100.43750 8 G YES 131.37500 9 T NO 80.75000 9 T YES 98.62500 10 T NO 62.62500 10 T YES 71.81250 11 T NO 79.75000 11 T YES 78.87500 12 G NO 75.56250 12 G YES 74.87500 14 T NO 80.87500 14 T YES 95.93750 15 G NO 73.56250 15 G YES 98.43750 16 T NO 92.50000 16 T YES 130.43750 17 G NO 66.18750 17 G YES 86.25000 18 T NO 64.18750 18 T YES 82.62500 19 T NO 86.93750 19 T YES 110.50000 20 G NO 81.00000 20 G YES 103.06250 21 G NO 65.43750 21 G YES 123.25000 22 T NO 93.06250 22 T YES 110.37500 23 T NO 50.56250 23 T YES 62.12500 Download data 5.1.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: Replace all occurrences of atorq with the name of your dependent variable. Replace all occurrences of group and supplement with the names of your independent variables, respectively. UNIANOVA atorq BY group supplement /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /INTERCEPT=INCLUDE /EMMEANS=TABLES(group) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(supplement) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*supplement) COMPARE(group) ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*supplement) COMPARE(supplement) ADJ(LSD) /PRINT ETASQ PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /DESIGN=group supplement group*supplement. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.7. 5.2 Two (or more) way within ANOVA Hypothesis Does strength training result in an improvement over a training session (PRE, POST) in the same group of people, and is the improvement dependent upon side (L, R)? 5.2.1 What your data needs to look like? subj POST_L POST_R PRE_L PRE_R 1 77.875 81.875 65.375 71.37500 2 60.000 62.750 40.500 52.50000 3 73.375 90.250 53.375 70.87500 4 98.500 99.250 59.500 66.25000 5 99.625 90.500 64.750 63.16164 6 112.625 116.500 82.750 87.12500 7 97.375 99.750 68.375 72.12500 8 126.500 136.250 104.125 96.75000 9 90.000 107.250 91.375 70.12500 10 65.875 77.750 60.000 65.25000 11 86.375 71.375 78.625 80.87500 12 79.500 70.250 82.375 68.75000 14 99.500 92.375 81.750 80.00000 15 103.500 93.375 60.500 86.62500 16 132.750 128.125 94.375 90.62500 17 78.625 93.875 58.250 74.12500 18 81.750 83.500 60.375 68.00000 19 96.375 124.625 86.125 87.75000 20 99.500 106.625 89.500 72.50000 21 131.875 114.625 61.750 69.12500 22 113.750 107.000 80.000 106.12500 23 63.125 61.125 45.250 55.87500 Download data 5.2.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: Notice I have four names: POST_L, POST_R, PRE_L, PRE_R. See the pattern? It is actually made up of two variables which we call here session (PRE, POST) and side (L, R). Change the column names to the merged names of all the independent within-subject variables you have. Replace session and side to any given name to these two common variables. GLM POST_L POST_R PRE_L PRE_R /WSFACTOR=session 2 Polynomial side 2 Polynomial /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(side) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session*side) COMPARE(session) ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session*side) COMPARE(side) ADJ(LSD) /PRINT=ETASQ PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /WSDESIGN=session side session*side. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.8. 5.3 Repeated (within-between) measures ANOVA Hypothesis Do different strength training methods (G and T) result in different ankle torque changes over session (PRE, POST)? 5.3.1 What your data needs to look like? subj group POST PRE 1 G 79.8750 68.37500 2 G 61.3750 46.50000 3 T 81.8125 62.12500 4 G 98.8750 62.87500 5 T 95.0625 63.95582 6 T 114.5625 84.93750 7 G 98.5625 70.25000 8 G 131.3750 100.43750 9 T 98.6250 80.75000 10 T 71.8125 62.62500 11 T 78.8750 79.75000 12 G 74.8750 75.56250 14 T 95.9375 80.87500 15 G 98.4375 73.56250 16 T 130.4375 92.50000 17 G 86.2500 66.18750 18 T 82.6250 64.18750 19 T 110.5000 86.93750 20 G 103.0625 81.00000 21 G 123.2500 65.43750 22 T 110.3750 93.06250 23 T 62.1250 50.56250 Download data 5.3.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: Replace all occurrences of atorq with the name of your dependent variable. Replace all occurrences of group with the name of your between group independent variable. Replace PRE and POST with the names of your columns which contains the repeat measured variable. You can have more than two really. All the repeated measured variable actually reflect categories within a single variable, which in this context we call session. You can given any name to this common variable. Change this common name, in this case session, to the name you have chosen in (4). GLM PRE POST BY group /WSFACTOR=session 2 Polynomial /MEASURE=atorq /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /POSTHOC=group(LSD T3) /PLOT=PROFILE(group*session) TYPE=LINE ERRORBAR=CI MEANREFERENCE=NO YAXIS=AUTO /EMMEANS=TABLES(group) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*session) COMPARE (session)ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*session) COMPARE (group)ADJ(LSD) /PRINT=DESCRIPTIVE ETASQ PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /WSDESIGN=session /DESIGN=group. For reporting, please see Chapter 6.9. 5.4 Linear mixed model Hypothesis Do different strength training methods (G and T) result in different ankle torque changes over session (PRE, POST)? 5.4.1 What your data needs to look like? subj group session atorq 1 G POST 79.87500 1 G PRE 68.37500 2 G POST 61.37500 2 G PRE 46.50000 3 T POST 81.81250 3 T PRE 62.12500 4 G POST 98.87500 4 G PRE 62.87500 5 T POST 95.06250 5 T PRE 63.95582 6 T POST 114.56250 6 T PRE 84.93750 7 G POST 98.56250 7 G PRE 70.25000 8 G POST 131.37500 8 G PRE 100.43750 9 T POST 98.62500 9 T PRE 80.75000 10 T POST 71.81250 10 T PRE 62.62500 11 T POST 78.87500 11 T PRE 79.75000 12 G POST 74.87500 12 G PRE 75.56250 14 T POST 95.93750 14 T PRE 80.87500 15 G POST 98.43750 15 G PRE 73.56250 16 T POST 130.43750 16 T PRE 92.50000 17 G POST 86.25000 17 G PRE 66.18750 18 T POST 82.62500 18 T PRE 64.18750 19 T POST 110.50000 19 T PRE 86.93750 20 G POST 103.06250 20 G PRE 81.00000 21 G POST 123.25000 21 G PRE 65.43750 22 T POST 110.37500 22 T PRE 93.06250 23 T POST 62.12500 23 T PRE 50.56250 Download data 5.4.2 Syntax Arguments to care about: Replace all occurrences of atorq with the name of your dependent variable. Replace all occurrences of group and session with the names of your independent variables, respectively. Replace all occurrences of subj with the name of your identifier variable - i.e. the name of the column that contains the unique patient name or number. MIXED atorq BY group session /CRITERIA=DFMETHOD(SATTERTHWAITE) CIN(95) MXITER(100) MXSTEP(10) SCORING(1) SINGULAR(0.000000000001) HCONVERGE(0.00000001, RELATIVE) LCONVERGE(0, ABSOLUTE) PCONVERGE(0, ABSOLUTE) /FIXED=group session group*session | SSTYPE(3) /METHOD=REML /PRINT=DESCRIPTIVES SOLUTION /RANDOM=INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(subj) COVTYPE(VC) SOLUTION /REPEATED=session | SUBJECT(subj) COVTYPE(DIAG) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(session) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*session) COMPARE(group) ADJ(LSD) /EMMEANS=TABLES(group*session) COMPARE(session) ADJ(LSD). For reporting, please see Chapter 6.10.

Chapter 6 Reporting 6.1 One-sample t test 6.2 Independent t-test 6.3 Paired t-test 6.4 One-way between ANOVA 6.5 One-way within ANOVA 6.6 Correlation 6.7 Two (or more) way between ANOVA 6.8 Two (or more) way within ANOVA 6.9 Repeated (within-between) measures ANOVA 6.10 Linear mixed model

Chapter 6 Reporting There is probably a tonne of guidelines to how one should report statistical findings in the Results section. How I report below is what I commonly do which has served me well. I believe it very closely approximates many guideline recommendations. 6.1 One-sample t test For running the test, please see chapter 4.1. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.1. Figure 6.1: One sample t test 6.1.1 Reporting Ankle torque in the present cohort was statistically significantly greater than the hypothesized mean by 24.11 Nm/kg (t = 7.14, P < 0.001, 95%CI 17.09 to 31.14 Nm/kg). 6.2 Independent t-test For running the test, please see chapter 4.2.After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.2. Figure 6.2: Two sample t test 6.2.1 Reporting Ankle torque in group G was not statistically different from group T, with a mean difference of -1.49 Nm/kg (t = -1.49, P = 0.833, 95%CI -15.97 to 13.00 Nm/kg). 6.3 Paired t-test For running the test, please see chapter 4.3. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.3. Figure 6.3: Paired t test 6.3.1 Reporting Ankle torque was 24.58 Nm/kg (t = 4.95, P < 0.001, 95%CI 13.34 to 35.81 Nm/kg) more after training than before training. 6.4 One-way between ANOVA For running the test, please see chapter 4.4. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.4 and 6.5. Figure 6.4: One-way between ANOVA primary results Figure 6.5: One-way between ANOVA post hoc 6.4.1 Reporting There was a significant effect of group on ankle torque (F = 5.06, P = 0.013). Group 2 was 24.58 Nm/kg (P = 0.004, 95%CI 8.73 to 40.42 Nm/kg) greater than group one, but was not significantly different from group 3 (P = 0.156, mean difference of 10.80 95%CI -4.38 to 25.98 Nm/kg). Group 3 was not significantly different from group 1 (P = 0.074, mean difference of 13.77 95%CI -1.40 to 28.95 Nm/kg). 6.5 One-way within ANOVA For running the test, please see chapter 4.5. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.6 and 6.7. Figure 6.6: One-way within ANOVA primary results Figure 6.7: One-way within ANOVA post hoc 6.5.1 Reporting There was a significant effect of session on ankle torque (F = 37.56, P < 0.001). Ankle torque in session 3 (after) was significantly greater than in session 2 (post) and 1 (pre), by 23.62 Nm/kg (P < 0.001, 95% CI 17.10 to 30.15 Nm/kg) and 19.67 Nm/kg (P < 0.001, 95% CI 13.43 to 25.92 Nm/kg), respectively. Ankle torque in session 2 was not significantly different from 1 (P = 0.142, mean difference of -3.95 95%CI -9.34 to 1.44 Nm/kg). 6.6 Correlation For running the test, please see chapter 4.6. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.8. Figure 6.8: Correlation 6.6.1 Reporting Ankle torque was significant correlated with ankle work with a magnitude of 0.99 (P < 0.001, 95%CI 0.98 to 1.00). 6.7 Two (or more) way between ANOVA For running the test, please see chapter 5.1. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.9 and 6.10. Figure 6.9: Two-way between ANOVA primary results Figure 6.10: Two-way between ANOVA post hoc 6.7.1 Reporting There was a non-significant group by supplement interaction on ankle torque (F = 0.257, P = 0.615). There was a significant main effect of supplements (F = 17.093, P < 0.001), where individuals taking supplements had 21.89 Nm/kg (95%CI 11.19 to 32.59 Nm/kg) greater ankle torque than those not taking supplements. There was no significant main effect of groups on ankle torque (F = 0.079, P = 0.780). 6.8 Two (or more) way within ANOVA For running the test, please see chapter 5.2. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.11 and 6.12. Figure 6.11: Two-way between ANOVA primary results Figure 6.12: Two-way between ANOVA post hoc 6.8.1 Reporting There was a non-significant session by side interaction on ankle torque (F = 0.303, P = 0.588). There was a significant main effect of sessions (F = 60.432, P < 0.001), where ankle torque was greater in session 1 than in session 2 by 21.65 Nm/kg (95%CI 15.86 to 27.44 Nm/kg). There was no significant main effect of side on ankle torque (F = 3.083, P = 0.094). 6.9 Repeated (within-between) measures ANOVA For running the test, please see chapter 5.3. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.13, 6.14 and 6.15. Figure 6.13: Repeated measures ANOVA primary results 1 Figure 6.14: Repeated measures ANOVA primary results 2 Figure 6.15: Repeated measures ANOVA post hoc 6.9.1 Reporting There was a non-significant group by session interaction effect on ankle torque (F = 0.918, P = 0.349). There was a significant main effect of sessions (F = 61.052, P < 0.001), where ankle torque was greater in session 2 than in session 1 by 21.89 Nm/kg (95%CI 16.05 to 27.74 Nm/kg). There was no significant main effect of group on ankle torque (F = 0.046, P = 0.833). 6.10 Linear mixed model For running the test, please see chapter 5.4. After running the test, this is what the result looks like in Figure 6.13, 6.14 and 6.15. Figure 6.16: Linear mixed model primary results Figure 6.17: Linear mixed model posthoc results 6.10.1 Reporting There was a non-significant group by session interaction effect on ankle torque (F = 0.918, P = 0.349). There was a significant main effect of sessions (F = 61.052, P < 0.001), where ankle torque was greater in session 2 than in session 1 by 21.89 Nm/kg (95%CI 16.05 to 27.74 Nm/kg). There was no significant main effect of group on ankle torque (F = 0.046, P = 0.833).
